title: 111_hr2991
content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, performance bonds by a principal, with certain conditions. The Act permits the Secretary to guarantee surety for eligible small businesses unable to obtain bonds on reasonable terms without a guarantee, with the expectation of performance. The Secretary can indemnify a surety against losses from avoiding breaches in connection with issuing a guarantee for a bond required by a contract. The Secretary can indemnify a surety against losses from avoiding breaches in connection with issuing a bond guarantee. The Secretary must approve any payments made by the surety, and payments from the Secretary cannot exceed 10 percent of the contract price unless deemed necessary. The Secretary can indemnify a surety for losses incurred in avoiding breaches related to bond guarantees. Payments from the Secretary cannot exceed 10 percent of the contract price unless the Secretary deems a greater payment necessary due to the surety's reasonable loss. The Secretary cannot pay the surety an amount exceeding the guaranteed share of the bond available. Additionally, the Secretary is obligated to reimburse the surety for a sum not exceeding 90 percent of the loss. The Secretary can indemnify a surety for losses incurred, paying up to 90 percent of the loss, with an exception relieving the Secretary of liability under certain conditions. The Secretary may reimburse the surety for losses incurred under certain conditions, with exceptions for fraud, breach of terms, or violation of regulations. The Secretary can establish regulations for participating sureties. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties regarding underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. Participating sureties may be reimbursed for paid losses based on prior monthly payments, with adjustments made after disbursement. Sureties are required to submit reports to the Secretary as per the regulations. The Secretary requires participating sureties to submit reports and allows audits of their documents. Sureties must be audited every three years. The Secretary administers this subsection prudently and economically. The Secretary requires participating sureties to be audited every three years by approved examiners. The Secretary administers this subsection prudently and establishes fees for small businesses and sureties. Additionally, the Secretary may select up to 5 states to carry out certain activities under this program. The program allows up to 5 states to participate in activities related to issuing guarantees and assisting small businesses. Selected states must meet prescribed standards and conditions set by the Secretary. The program allows up to 5 states to participate in issuing guarantees and assisting small businesses. Selected states must meet prescribed standards and conditions. States must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing the program's nature, total guarantees provided, and the number of participating small businesses. The Secretary must submit an annual report to specific committees describing program details. The Secretary must annually report to specific committees on the implementation of the program, including the number of sureties receiving guarantees, participating states, small businesses involved, and guarantees paid. Additionally, the report must include the number of states applying to manage program funds. The Secretary must report annually on the program, including the number of sureties receiving guarantees, participating states, small businesses involved, guarantees paid, and states applying to manage program funds. Definitions for "bid bond" and "eligible small business concern" are provided. The term 'eligible small business concern' refers to a small business owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, service-disabled veterans, or qualified HUBZone small businesses. The term 'obligee' refers to the person requesting bids for a contract in the case of a bid bond. The term 'payment bond' refers to a bond ensuring the principal pays money to contracted individuals. The curr_chunk defines terms related to bonds and contractors, including payment bond, performance bond, prime contractor, and principal bidding for a contract award. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to contractors and bonds, including the definitions of principal, Secretary, and subcontractor. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to contractors and bonds, including the definitions of Secretary, subcontractor, and surety. Under a performance bond, the surety agrees to cover the costs of fulfilling a contract if the principal breaches it. Additionally, a payment bond ensures payment to labor and material suppliers if the principal fails to pay promptly. The surety can also act as an agent or underwriter on behalf of the principal. The surety can act as an agent, independent agent, underwriter, or any other empowered individual on behalf of the principal. Authorization of appropriations is set at $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2010 through 2014, with $20,000,000 available each year for specific activities. SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include "any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation".

SEC. 4. PROVISION OF RELEVANT INFORMATION.

Amends Section 332(d) of title 49, United States Code by striking specific entities.
